Question 1 Consider the two-dimensional vector field [latex]\vec{F}(x,y)=x\vec{i}+y\vec{j}[/latex], where [latex]\vec{i}[/latex] and [latex]\vec{j}[/latex] denote
the unit vectors along the x-axis and the y-axis, respectively. A contour C in the x-y plane, as shown in the figure, is composed of two horizontal lines connected at the
two ends by two semicircular arcs of unit radius. The contour is traversed in the
counter-clockwise sense. The value of the closed path integral [latex]\oint _c \vec{F}(x,y)\cdot (dx\vec{i}+dy\vec{j})[/latex]
solution:
[latex]\oint \vec{F} (x,y)\cdot [dx\vec{i}+dy\vec{j}][/latex] Given [latex]\vec{F} (x,y)=x\vec{i}+y\vec{j}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \int_{c}xdx+ydy=0[/latex] Because here vector is conservative. If the integral function is the total derivative
over the closed contoure then it will be zero

question: Question 3 The current [latex]I[/latex] in the circuit shown is ________
solution:
Applying Nodal equation at Node-A [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{V_A}{2k}+\frac{V_A-5}{2k}&=10^{-3}\\
\Rightarrow 2V_A-5&=2k \times 10^{-3}\\
V_A&=3.5V\\
Again,&\\
I&=\frac{5-V_A}{2k}\\
&=\frac{5-3.5}{2k}\\
&=0.75 \times 10^{-3}A
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 5 The Fourier transform [latex]X(j\omega )[/latex] of the signal [latex]x(t)=\frac{t}{(1+t^2)^2}[/latex] is   _________.
solution:
[latex]x(t)=\frac{t}{(1+t^2)^2}[/latex] As we know that FT of 
 [latex]te^{-|t|} \; \underleftrightarrow{FT} \;\frac{-j4\omega }{(1+\omega ^2)^2}[/latex] Duality 
 [latex]\frac{-j4\omega }{(1+t ^2)^2} \leftrightarrow 2 \pi(-\omega )e^{-|-\omega |}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow  \frac{t}{(1+t^2)^2} \underrightarrow{FT} \frac{-2\pi}{-j4}\omega e^{-|\omega |}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \;\;\;\rightarrow\frac{\pi}{j2} \omega e^{-|\omega |}[/latex]

question:
Question 6 Consider a long rectangular bar of direct bandgap p-type semiconductor. The
equilibrium hole density is [latex]10^{17}cm^{-3}[/latex] and the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex]. Electron and hole diffusion lengths are [latex]2\mu m[/latex]and [latex]1\mu m[/latex], respectively.
The left side of the bar ([latex]x=0[/latex]) is uniformly illuminated with a laser having photon
energy greater than the bandgap of the semiconductor. Excess electron-hole pairs
are generated ONLY at [latex]x=0[/latex] because of the laser. The steady state electron density
at [latex]x=0[/latex] is [latex]10^{14}cm^{-3}[/latex]
 due to laser illumination. Under these conditions and ignoring
electric field, the closest approximation (among the given options) of the steady state
electron density at [latex]x=2 \mu m[/latex], is _____
solution:
From continuity equation of electrons [latex]\frac{dn}{dt}=n\mu _n\frac{dE}{dx}+\mu _nE\frac{dn}{dx}+G_n-R_n+x_n\frac{d^2x}{dx^2} \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] [Because 
 [latex]\vec{E}[/latex] is not mentioned hence [latex]\frac{dE}{dx}=0[/latex] For 
 [latex] x \gt 0, G_n[/latex]  is also zero [latex]n=\frac{n_i^2}{N_A}=\frac{10^{20}}{10^{17}}=10^3[/latex] [latex]n=n_0+\delta n=10^3+10^{14}=10^{14}[/latex] at steady state, 
[latex]\frac{db}{dt}=0[/latex] Hence equation (i) becomes: [latex]O=D_n\frac{d^2\delta n}{dx^2}-\frac{\delta n}{\tau _n}[/latex] [latex]\frac{d^2\delta n}{dx^2}=\frac{\delta n}{L_n^2} \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] From solving equation (ii) [latex]\delta _n(x)=\delta _n(0)e^{-x/L_n}[/latex] at  
[latex]x=2\mu m[/latex] [latex]\delta _n(2\mu m)=10^{14}e^{-2/2}=10^{14}e^{-1}=0.37 \times 10^{14}[/latex]

question:
Question 7 In a non-degenerate bulk semiconductor with electron density [latex]n=10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], the
value of [latex]E_C-E_{Fn}=200meV[/latex], where [latex]E_C[/latex] and [latex]E_{Fn}[/latex] denote the bottom of the
conduction band energy and electron Fermi level energy, respectively. Assume
thermal voltage as 26 meV and the intrinsic carrier concentration is [latex]10^{10}cm^{-3}[/latex]. For [latex]n=0.5 \times 10^{16}cm^{-3}[/latex], the closest approximation of the value of ([latex]E_C-E_{Fn}[/latex]), among
the given options, is ______.
solution:
Here we have to find the value of
[latex]E_c-E_{fn}[/latex] As we know, [latex]E_C-E_F=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n} \right ) \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex]E_C-E_{F1}=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n_1} \right ) \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] [latex]E_C-E_{F2}=kT \ln\left ( \frac{N_c}{n_2} \right ) \;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] Equation (ii) - Equation (iii) [latex](E_C-E_{F1})-(E_C-E_{F2})=kT \ln \left ( \frac{\frac{N_c}{n_1}}{\frac{N_c}{n_2}} \right )=kT \ln \frac{n_2}{n_1}[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow 200meV-(E_C-E_{F2})=26meV \times \ln \left ( \frac{0.5 \times 10^{16}}{1 \times 10^{16}} \right )[/latex] [latex] 200meV-(E_C-E_{F2})=+26meV \ln (0.5)=-18[/latex] [latex](E_C-E_{F2})=200+8=218meV[/latex]

Question 8 Consider the CMOS circuit shown in the figure (substrates are connected to their
respective sources). The gate width ([latex]W[/latex]) to gate length ([latex]L[/latex]) ratios [latex]\frac{W}{L}[/latex] of the
transistors are as shown. Both the transistors have the same gate oxide capacitance
per unit area. For the pMOSFET, the threshold voltage is -1 V and the mobility of
holes is [latex]40\frac{cm^2}{V.s}[/latex]. For the nMOSFET, the threshold voltage is 1 V and the mobility
of electrons is [latex]300\frac{cm^2}{V.s}[/latex]. The steady state output voltage [latex]V_o[/latex] is ________.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\mu _PCO_x\left ( \frac{\omega }{L} \right )_1[4-V_0-1]^2&=\mu _nCO_x\left ( \frac{\omega }{L} \right )_2[V_0-0-1]^2\\
\Rightarrow \frac{300}{40}\times \frac{1}{5}(V_0-1)^2&=(3-V_0)^2\\
\Rightarrow \sqrt{1.5}
(V_0-1)&=3-V_0\\
\Rightarrow V_0&=\frac{3+\sqrt{1.5}}{\sqrt{1.5}+1} \lt 2V

\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 13 The frequency response [latex]H(f)[/latex] of a linear time-invariant system has magnitude as
shown in the figure. Statement I: The system is necessarily a pure delay system for inputs which are
bandlimited to [latex]-\alpha \leq f\leq \alpha  [/latex]. Statement II: For any wide-sense stationary input process with power spectral
density [latex]S_X(f) [/latex], the output power spectral density [latex]S_Y(f) [/latex] obeys [latex]S_Y(f)=S_X(f) [/latex] for [latex]-\alpha \leq f\leq \alpha  [/latex]. Which one of the following combinations is true?
solution:
For the system to be delay system [latex] \begin{aligned}
 y(t)&=x(t-t_d) \\ 
 y(F)&=e^{-J\omega t_d}  \times F\\ 
 \Rightarrow H(F)&=\frac{Y(F)}{X(F)}=e^{-J\omega t_d} 
\end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, TF of delay system Here given system is constant, hence this is
not delay system, therefore statement-I is Incorrect [latex] S_y(f)=S_x(f)|H(f)|^2[/latex] and [latex] |H(f)|=1 (given)[/latex] Hence, 
[latex]S_y(f)=S_x(f)\; for \; -\alpha \leq f\leq \alpha  [/latex] Statement - II is correct.

options.A: Statement I is correct, Statement II is correct
options.B: Statement I is correct, Statement II is incorrect
options.C: Statement I is incorrect, Statement II is correct
options.D: Statement I is incorrect, Statement II is incorrect

question:
Question 15 Consider the following partial differential equation (PDE) [latex]a\frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial x^2} +b\frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial y^2}=f(x,y)[/latex] ,
where [latex]a[/latex]and [latex]b[/latex] are distinct positive real numbers. Select the combination(s) of values
of the real parameters [latex]\xi [/latex] and [latex]\eta  [/latex] such that [latex]f(x,y)=e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}  [/latex] is a solution of the
given PDE.
solution:
Given [latex] \begin{aligned}
 f(x,y)&=e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}\\
\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x}&=\xi \cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}\\
\frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial x^2}&=\xi ^2\cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}\\
\end{aligned}[/latex] Similarly, [latex] \frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial y^2}=\eta ^2\cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}[/latex] Now, as given [latex]a \frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial x^2}+b\frac{\partial^2 f(x,y)}{\partial y^2}=f(x,y)[/latex] or [latex]a \times \xi ^2\cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}+b \times  \eta  ^2\cdot e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}= e^{(\xi x+\eta y)}[/latex] [latex] a\cdot \xi ^2+b\cdot \eta ^2=1[/latex] Thus,  
[latex]\xi =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2a}}, \eta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2b}}[/latex] [latex](\xi =\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}}, \eta = 0)[/latex] and [latex](\xi =0, \eta = \frac{1}{\sqrt{b}})[/latex] satisfy the above result.

question: Question 22 A simple closed path [latex]C[/latex] in the complex plane is shown in the figure. If [latex] \oint C\frac{2^z}{z^2-1}dz=-i \pi A [/latex] where [latex] i=\sqrt{-1} [/latex], then the value of [latex] A [/latex] is ______ (rounded off to two decimal places)

Question 23 Let [latex] x_1(t)=e^{-t}u(t) [/latex] and [latex] x_2(t)=u(t)-u(t-2) [/latex], where [latex] u(\cdot) [/latex] denotes the unit step
function.
If [latex] y(t) [/latex] denotes the convolution of [latex] x_1(t)[/latex] and [latex] x_2(t)[/latex], then [latex] \lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }y(t)=[/latex] _________
(rounded off to one decimal place).
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
x_1(t)=e^{-1}U(t)&\underleftrightarrow{L.T.}\frac{1}{(s+1)}\\
x_2(t)=U(t)-U(t-2)&\underleftrightarrow{L.T.}\frac{1}{s}-\frac{e^{-2s}}{s}=\frac{1-e^{-2s}}{s}\\
y(t)=x_1(t)\otimes x_2(t)&\underleftrightarrow{L.T.} \frac{(1-e^{-2s})}{s(s+1)} \\
y(t)&\underleftrightarrow{L.T.}\frac{1-e^{-2s}}{s(s+1)}\\
\lim_{t \to \infty }y(t)&=\lim_{s \to 0 }\frac{s(1-e^{-2s})}{s(s+1)}=0
\end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 25 A symbol stream contains alternate QPSK and 16-QAM symbols. If symbols from
this stream are transmitted at the rate of 1 mega-symbols per second, the raw
(uncoded) data rate is _______ mega-bits per second (rounded off to one decimal
place).
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
\text{BIT RATE}&=[\text{SYBOL RATE}] \times \log_{20}M\\
1.\;\; QPSK, \; M&=4,n=2\\
R_{b1}&=1 \times 2 =2mbps\\
2.\;\; 16 QAM_1\Rightarrow  M=16,n=4\\
R_{b2}&=1 \times 4=4mbps\\
R_b&=\frac{2m+4m}{2}\\
R_b&=3 mbps
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 26 The function [latex] f(x)=8 \log _e x-x^2+3[/latex] attains its minimum over the interval
[latex] [1,e][/latex]  at [latex] x=[/latex] _________. (Here [latex]  \log _e x[/latex] is the natural logarithm of [latex] x=[/latex].)
solution:
[latex]f(x)=8 \log _e x-x^2+3 [/latex] when 
[latex] x \in [1,e][/latex] Differentiating both side, [latex] \begin{aligned}
f(x)&=\frac{8}{x}-2x=0 \; where\; x \gt  0\\
f'(x)&=0\\
\frac{8}{x}-2x&=0\\
8-2x^2&=0\\
x^2&=4\\
x&=\pm 2
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
f''(x)&=\frac{-8}{x^2}-2 \\
f''(2)&=-6 \lt  0\\

\end{aligned}[/latex] f(x) is maximum for x = 2 Minimum of f(x) will be in [1, e]
= min [f(1), f(e)] [latex] f(e)=8 \ln e -e^2+3=3.61[/latex] Hence, minimum value of f(x) occurs at x=1

question:
Question 27 Let [latex] \alpha ,\beta [/latex] be two non-zero real numbers and [latex]v_1,v_2[/latex] be two non-zero real vectors of
size 3 x 1. Suppose that [latex]v_1[/latex] and [latex]v_2[/latex] satisfy [latex]v_1^Tv_2=0,v_1^Tv_1=1[/latex], and [latex]v_2^Tv_2=1[/latex]. Let [latex]A[/latex] be the 3x3 matrix given by: [latex] A=\alpha v_1v_1^T+ \beta v_2v_2^T[/latex] The eigenvalues of [latex]A[/latex] are __________.
solution:
After multiply by [latex] v_1[/latex] on both sides, [latex] \begin{aligned}
Av_1&=\alpha v_1v_1^Tv_1+ \beta v_2v_2^Tv_1
Av_1&=\alpha v_1
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \alpha [/latex] is an eigen value of A. After multiply by [latex] v_2[/latex] on both sides, [latex] \begin{aligned}
Av_2&=\alpha v_1v_1^Tv_2+ \beta v_2v_2^Tv_2
Av_2&=\beta v_2
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \beta [/latex] is an eigen value of A. [latex] v_1v_1^T [/latex] and [latex] v_2v_2^T [/latex]  both are singular matrieces. Therefore, A is also a singular matrix. [latex] |A|=0\Rightarrow \lambda _A=0[/latex] Hence [latex] \lambda _A= 0,\alpha ,\beta [/latex]

question:
Question 28 For the circuit shown, the locus of the impedance [latex] Z(j\omega )[/latex] is plotted as [latex]\omega [/latex] increases
from zero to infinity. The values of [latex] R_1[/latex] and [latex] R_2[/latex] are:
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
Z(j\omega )&=R_1+\frac{R_2\cdot 1/j\omega c}{R_2+ 1/j\omega c}\\
&=R_1+\frac{R_2}{\frac{1}{2}+jR_2\omega c}\\
Z(j\omega )_{\omega =0}&=R_1+R_2\\
\Rightarrow R_1+R_2&=5k\Omega \\
Z|j\omega |_{\omega \rightarrow \infty }&=R_1\\
\Rightarrow R_1&=2k\Omega \\
 R_2&=3k\Omega 
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 30 Consider an ideal long channel nMOSFET (enhancement-mode) with gate length [latex] 10\mu m[/latex] and width [latex] 100\mu m[/latex]. The product of electron mobility ([latex] \mu _n[/latex]) and oxide
capacitance per unit area ([latex] C_{OX}[/latex]) is [latex]\mu _n C_{OX}=1mA/V^2[/latex]. The threshold voltage of the
transistor is 1 V. For a gate-to-source voltage [latex]V_{GS}=[2-\sin (2t)]V [/latex] and drain-tosource voltage [latex]V_{DS}=1V [/latex] (substrate connected to the source), the maximum value
of the drain-to-source current is ________.
solution:
[latex] \mu _n Co_x=1mA/V^2; W=100\mu m;L=10\mu m[/latex] [latex] V_T= \perp V; V_{GS}=[2-\sin 2t]V;V_{DS}=1V[/latex] Let, [latex] \begin{aligned}
V_{GS} &=3V(max)\\
\Rightarrow V_{DS} &\lt V_{GS}-V_t\\
\because \; 1 &\lt (3-1)
\end{aligned}[/latex] MOSFET in triode region [latex] \begin{aligned}
I_{Dmax}&=\mu _CO_x\left ( \frac{\omega }{L} \right )\left \{ \left ( V_{as \; max}-V_t \right )V_{DS}-\frac{1}{2}V_{DS}^2 \right \}\\
&=1 \times \left ( \frac{100}{10} \right )\left \{ (3-1) \times 1-\frac{1}{2} \times 1^2 \right \}mA\\
&=10(2-1/2)\\
&=15mA
\end{aligned}[/latex]

 s^3& 0 & 0 & \\ 
 s^2&  &  & \\ 
 s&  &  & \\ 
 s^0&  &  & 
\end{matrix}[/latex] [latex] s^4+5s^2+(4+k)=0[/latex] [latex] 4s^3+10s=0[/latex] [latex](4s^2+10)=0 [/latex] [latex]s=\pm j\sqrt{5/2} [/latex] [latex] \begin{matrix}

question: Question 35 Consider the following series: [latex]\sum_{n=1}^{\infty }\frac{n^d}{c^n} [/latex] For which of the following combinations of [latex]c,d[/latex] values does this series converge?
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
\Sigma u_n&=\Sigma \frac{n}{2^n}\\
&\text{Ratio test; }\\
\lim_{n \to \infty }\frac{u_{n+1}}{u_n}&=\lim_{n \to \infty }\frac{n+1}{2^{n+1}} \times \frac{2^n}{n}=\frac{1}{2}\\
\frac{1}{2}& \lt 2
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore  [/latex] By ratio test, 
[latex] \Sigma u_n [/latex] is convergent. (A) c=1, d=-1 [latex]\Sigma u_n=\Sigma \frac{1}{n} [/latex] is divergent by P-test (B) c=0.5, d=-10 [latex]  \begin{aligned}
\Sigma u_n&=\Sigma \frac{n^{-10}}{(0.5)^n}\\
&\text{Ratio test; }\\
\lim_{n \to \infty }\frac{u_{n+1}}{u_n}&=\lim_{n \to \infty }\frac{(n+1)^{-10}}{(0.5)^{n+1}} \times \frac{(0.5)^n}{n^{10}}\\
&=\frac{1}{0.5}=2\\
2& \gt 1
\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\therefore  [/latex] By ratio test, 
[latex] \Sigma u_n [/latex] is divergent. (D)  c=1,d=-2
[latex]\Sigma u_n=\Sigma \frac{n^{-2}}{(1)^n}=\Sigma \frac{1}{n^2} [/latex] [latex] \Sigma u_n [/latex] is convergent by P-test.

question:
Question 39 Consider a Boolean gate (D) where the output [latex]Y[/latex] is related to the inputs [latex]A[/latex] and [latex]B[/latex] as,
[latex]Y=A+\bar{B} [/latex], where + denotes logical OR operation. The Boolean inputs '0' and '1'
are also available separately. Using instances of only D gates and inputs '0' and '1',
__________ (select the correct option(s)).
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
y &=A+\bar{B} =\overline{\bar{A}\cdot B}\\ 
 f(A,B)&=A+\bar{B} \\ 
f(0,B) &=0+\bar{B}=\bar{B}\Rightarrow NOT\; Gate \\ 
f(A,\bar{B}) &=A+\bar{\bar{B}} =A+B\Rightarrow OR \;Gate\\ 
 f(0,f(A,\bar{B}))&=0+(\overline{A+B})\Rightarrow NOR \; Gate \\ 
f(\bar{A},B) &= \bar{A}+\bar{B}=\overline{A\cdot B}\Rightarrow NAND\; Gate\\ 
 f(0,f(\bar{A},B))&=0+\overline{\overline{A\cdot B}} =A\cdot B\Rightarrow AND \; Gate
\end{aligned}[/latex] Since, we can implement NOT Gate we can
also implement OR, AND, NOR and NAND Gate.

question:

2\xi _1 \times \sqrt{10}&=\sqrt{10}\\
\xi _2&=1/2\\

overshoot. [latex]\omega _{d_1}=\omega _{n_1}\sqrt{1-\xi ^2} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \omega _{d_1}\neq \omega _{d_2} \;\; \because \omega _{n_1}\neq \omega _{n_2}[/latex] damped frequency of oscillation is not same. [latex] \begin{aligned}
T_s &=\frac{4}{\xi \omega _n}(2%\; setting \; time) \\ 
T_{s_1} &\neq  T_{s_2} \;\because \omega _{n_1}\neq \omega _{n_2}\\ 
C_1(s) &= \frac{10 \times 1/s}{s^2+s+1}\\ 
C_{ss} &=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C_1(s) \\ 
 &= 10\\ 
C_2(s) &= \frac{10 \times 1/s}{s^2+\sqrt{10}s+10}\\ 
C_{ss} &=\lim_{s \to 0}s\cdot C_2(s) \\ 
 &= \frac{10}{10}1=1

 from \; (i)&,(ii),(iii) \\

question:
Question 43 The value of the integral [latex] \int \int _D 3(x^2+y^2)dxdy[/latex] ,
where [latex]D[/latex] is the shaded triangular region shown in the diagram, is _____ (rounded off
to the nearest integer).
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
I&=\int_{0}^{4}\int_{-x}^{x}(3x^2+3y^2)dydx\\
&=\int_{0}^{4}\left [ 3x^y+\frac{3y^3}{3} \right ]_{-x}^xdx\\
&=\int_{0}^{4}[3x^2(2x)+2x^3]dx\\
&=\int_{0}^{4}8x^3 dx\\
&=2 \times 4^4\\
&=512
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 For a vector [latex] \bar{x}=\left [x[0],x[1],...,x[7]  \right ][/latex], the 8-point discrete Fourier transform (DFT)
is denoted by [latex] \bar{X}=DFT(\bar{x})=\left [X[0],X[1],...,X[7]  \right ][/latex], where [latex] X[k]=\sum_{n=0}^{7}x[n]exp\left ( -j\frac{2 \pi}{8}nk \right )[/latex] Here, [latex] j=\sqrt{-1}[/latex]. If [latex] \bar{x}==[1,0,0,0,2,0,0,0][/latex] and [latex] \bar{y}=DFT(DFT(\bar{x}))[/latex], then the value
of [latex]y[0][/latex] is _________ (rounded off to one decimal place).
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned}
X[K]&=\sum_{n=0}^{7}x[n]exp\left ( -j\frac{2\pi}{8}mk \right )\\
\bar{y}&=DFT(DFT(\bar{x})) \; \; where\\
\bar{x}&=[x[0],x[1],...,x[7]]\\
y(0)&=? \;\;x[n]=[1,0,0,0,2,0,0,0]\\
x[n]&\overset{DFT}{\rightarrow}\overset{DFT}{\rightarrow}N\cdot x(-k)=\bar{y}(n)\\
\bar{y}(n)&=N\cdot x(-k)|_{mod.N}=N\cdot x(N.K),N=8\\
\bar{y}(n)&=8[1,0,0,0,2,0,0,0]\\
\bar{y}(n)&=[8,0,0,0,16,0,0,0]\\
y(0)&=8
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 46 A p-type semiconductor with zero electric field is under illumination (low level
injection) in steady state condition. Excess minority carrier density is zero at [latex] x=\pm 2l_n[/latex], where [latex] l_n=10^{-4} cm[/latex] is the diffusion length of electrons. Assume
electronic charge, [latex] q=-1.6 \times 10^{-19}C[/latex]. The profiles of photo-generation rate of
carriers and the recombination rate of excess minority carriers (R) are shown. Under
these conditions, the magnitude of the current density due to the photo-generated
electrons at [latex] x=+2l_n[/latex] is _________ [latex] mA/cm^2[/latex]
 (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
Given, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\delta _n(x)&=R\tau _n=10^{20}e^{-|x|/l_n}\cdot \tau _n\\
\delta (l_n)&=10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n \;\;\;...(i)\\
for \;\; l_n\leq x\leq 2l_n
\end{aligned}[/latex] Continuity equation is given by [latex] D_n\frac{\partial^2 \delta _n}{\partial x^2}+G-R \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] G and R both are zero - for
[latex] [l_n\leq x\leq 2l_n][/latex] Hence Equation (i) reduced to 
[latex] D_n \frac{\partial^n \delta _n }{\partial x^2}=0[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \delta _n(x)=Ax+B[/latex] For calculating A and B we use Boundary
condition [latex] \delta _n(2l_n)=0\; \Rightarrow A=\frac{-B}{2l_n}[/latex] [latex] \therefore \delta _n(x)=\frac{-B}{2l_n}x+B=B\left [ 1-\frac{x}{2l_n} \right ] \;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] At 
[latex]x=l_n [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
 10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n&=B\left [ 1-\frac{l_n}{2l_n} \right ] \\ 
 B&= 2 \times 10^{20}e^{-1}\tau _n\\ 
\therefore \; \delta _n(x) &=2 \times 10^{20} e^{-1}\tau _n\left [ 1-\frac{x}{2l_n} \right ]
\end{aligned} [/latex] for [latex]l_n \leq x \leq 2l_n [/latex] Electron diffusion current density is given by
[latex] |J_n|_{diff}=qD_n\frac{d\eta }{dx}=qD_n \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1} \times \tau _n\left [ 0-\frac{1}{2l_n} \right ][/latex] [latex] =\frac{1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times l_n ^2 \times 2 \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1}}{2l_n}[/latex] [latex]=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times l_n  \times 10^{20} \times e^{-1} [/latex] [latex] =1.6 \times 10 \times 1 \times 10^{-4} \times e^{-1}[/latex] [latex] =0.59mA/cm^2[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A circuit and the characteristics of the diode (D) in it are shown. The ratio of the
minimum to the maximum small signal voltage gain [latex] \frac{\partial V_{out}}{\partial V_{in}}[/latex] is ________ (rounded
off to two decimal places)
solution:
Replacing the given circuit with small signal equivalent. Case-I when diode is ON As [latex] r_d(ON)=0,[/latex] the 
[latex] 2k\Omega [/latex] resistor in parallel to
the diode becomes open circuit. [latex] \therefore \; V_{out}=V_{IN}\times \frac{2}{4}=\frac{V_{in}}{2}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; \frac{\partial V_{out}}{\partial V_{in}}|_{max}=\frac{1}{2}\;\;\;...(i) [/latex] Case-I: When diode is off: [latex] r_d(off)=\infty \Rightarrow total \; R_{eq}=2+2+2=6k\Omega [/latex] [latex] \therefore \; V_{out}=\frac{V_{in} \times 4}{6}=\frac{2}{3}V_{in}\Rightarrow \frac{\partial V_{out}}{\partial V_{in}}|_{min}=\frac{2}{3}\;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] From (i) and (ii) [latex] \frac{\left (\frac{\partial V_{out}}{\partial V_{in}}\right )_{min}}{\left (\frac{\partial V_{out}}{\partial V_{in}}\right )_{max}}=\frac{1/2}{2/3}=0.75[/latex]

question:
Question 48 Consider the circuit shown with an ideal OPAMP. The output voltage [latex]V_o[/latex] is

[latex]V_A=\frac{V_R}{2} \; and R_{th}=R [/latex] [latex] V_B=\frac{V_B}{2}[/latex] [latex] V_C=\frac{(V_R+V_R/4)}{2}=\frac{5}{8}V_R[/latex] [latex] R_{th}=2R||2R=R[/latex] Similarly, [latex]V_D=\frac{V_C}{2}=\frac{5}{16}V_R [/latex] So,

question:
Question 50 The block diagram of a closed-loop control system is shown in the figure. R(s),Y(s) and D(s) are the Laplace transforms of the time-domain signals [latex]r(t),y(t),[/latex] and [latex]d(t)[/latex], respectively. Let the error signal be defined as [latex]e(t)=r(t)-y(t)[/latex]. Assuming the
reference input [latex]r(t)=0[/latex] for all [latex]t[/latex], the steady-state error [latex]e(\infty )[/latex], due to a unit step
disturbance [latex]d(t)[/latex], is _________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]Y(s)=\frac{R(s)\cdot \frac{10}{s(s+10)}}{1+\frac{10}{s(s+10)}} +\frac{D(s)\cdot \frac{10}{s(s+10)}}{1+\frac{10}{s(s+10)}}[/latex] When, 
[latex] r(t)=0\; and \; d(t)=U(t)\underleftrightarrow{L.T.}\frac{1}{s}[/latex] [latex] e(\infty )=-\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{s\cdot \frac{1}{s} \times 1}{s(s+10)+10} =-1/10=-0.1\;\;\;(\because e(t)=r(t)-y(t))[/latex]

question:
Question 51 The transition diagram of a discrete memoryless channel with three input symbols
and three output symbols is shown in the figure. The transition probabilities are as
marked. The parameter [latex] \alpha [/latex] lies in the interval [0.25, 1]. The value of [latex] \alpha [/latex] for which the capacity
of this channel is maximized, is ________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
Channel capacity, [latex]C_s=Max[I(X:Y)] [/latex] [latex]I[(X:Y)]=H(Y)-H\left ( \frac{Y}{X} \right ) [/latex] Where, [latex] H\left ( \frac{Y}{X} \right )=-\sum_{i=1}^{3}\sum_{i=1}^{3}P(x_i,y_i) \log_2P\left ( \frac{y_i}{x_i} \right )[/latex] [latex] P\left ( \frac{Y}{X} \right )=\begin{matrix}
 &y_1  & y_2 & y_3\\ 
x_1 &1-\alpha   & \alpha  & 0\\ 
x_2 &0  &1-\alpha   &\alpha  \\ 
x_3 & \alpha  & 0 & 1-\alpha 
\end{matrix}[/latex] For simplication convenience, let
[latex][P(X)]=[1\;\;0\;\;0] [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
[P(X,Y)]&=[P(X)]_d\cdot \left [ P\left ( \frac{Y}{X} \right ) \right ]\\
[P(X,Y)]&=\begin{bmatrix}
1-\alpha  & \alpha  &0 \\ 
 0&  0&0 \\ 
0 & 0 &0 
\end{bmatrix}\\
H\left ( \frac{Y}{X} \right )&=-((1-\alpha ) \log_2 (1-\alpha )+\alpha  \log _2 \alpha )\\
I(X:Y)&=H(Y)+(1-\alpha ) \log_2 (1-\alpha )+ \log _2 \alpha \\
C_s&=MAX\left \{ (X:Y) \right \}\\
&=MAX\left \{ H(Y)+(1-\alpha ) \log_2 (1-\alpha )+ \log _2 \alpha \right \}\\
&=log_2 3+(1-\alpha ) \log_2 (1-\alpha )+\alpha  \log _2 \alpha
\end{aligned} [/latex] Plot of 

[latex] (1-\alpha ) \log_2 (1-\alpha )+\alpha  \log _2 \alpha[/latex] [latex] C_s[/latex] will be maximum at [latex]\alpha =0 [/latex] and 1. Given 
[latex] \alpha \in [0.25,1][/latex] Hence, [latex]\alpha =1 [/latex] is correct answer.

Question 52 Consider communication over a memoryless binary symmetric channel using a
(7, 4) Hamming code. Each transmitted bit is received correctly with probability [latex] (1-\epsilon ) [/latex], and flipped with probability [latex] \epsilon  [/latex]. For each codeword transmission, the receiver
performs minimum Hamming distance decoding, and correctly decodes the message
bits if and only if the channel introduces at most one bit error. For [latex] \epsilon =0.1 [/latex], the probability that a transmitted codeword is decoded correctly is
_________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
Here (7, 4) Hamming code is given P(0/1) = P(1/0) (due to bindary symmetry
channel) = 0.1 When n bits are transmitted then probability of getting error in [latex]\gamma  [/latex] bits [latex] = ^nC_rP^r(1-p)^{n-r}[/latex] P:Bit error probability [latex]P_c=C_0(0.1)^0[1-0.1]^{7-0}+^7C_1(0.1)(1-0.1)^{7-1}=(0.9)^7+7 \times 0.1 \times (0.9)^6=0.85 [/latex] [latex] P_C[/latex] 
: Prob of all most one bit error.

question:
Question 53 Consider a channel over which either symbol [latex] x_A [/latex] or symbol [latex] x_B [/latex] is transmitted. Let the
output of the channel Y be the input to a maximum likelihood (ML) detector at the
receiver. The conditional probability density functions for Y given [latex] x_A [/latex]and [latex] x_B [/latex] are: [latex] f_{Y|x_A}(y)=e^{-(y+1)}u(y+1), [/latex] [latex] f_{Y|x_B}(y)=e^{(y-1)}(1-u(y-1)), [/latex] where [latex] u(\cdot ) [/latex] is the standard unit step function. The probability of symbol error for this
system is _________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
ML decoding [latex] \rightarrow \; f_{Y/X_A}(y)\underset{\overset{ \lt }{X_B}}{\overset{X_A}{ \gt }} f_{Y/X_B}(y)[/latex] [latex]i.e. \;\; f_{Y/X_A}(y)  \gt f_{Y/X_B}(y) \rightarrow \text{ Decision favor of }X_A[/latex] [latex]i.e. \;\; f_{Y/X_A}(y)  \lt  f_{Y/X_B}(y) \rightarrow \text{ Decision favor of }X_B[/latex] For 
[latex]-1 \lt y \lt 0 [/latex] and 
[latex] 1 \lt y \lt \infty \rightarrow f_{Y/X_A}(y)  \gt f_{Y/X_B}(y)[/latex] For above internal decision in favor of 
[latex]X_A [/latex] For 
[latex]-\infty  \lt y \lt -1 [/latex] and 
[latex] 0\lt y \lt 1 \rightarrow f_{Y/X_B}(y) \gt f_{Y/X_A}(y)[/latex] For above internal decision in favor of 
[latex]X_B [/latex] [latex]P_e=P(X_A)\cdot P_{eX_A}+P(X_B)\cdot P_{eX_A} [/latex] [latex] P_{eX_A}\rightarrow[/latex] Probability of error  [latex] X_A[/latex] transmitted [latex] P_{eX_B}\rightarrow[/latex] Probability of error [latex] X_B[/latex] transmitted [latex]P_{eX_A}=\int_{0}^{1} f_{Y/X_A}(y)dy=\int_{0}^{1}e^{-(y+1)}u(y+1)dy= \int_{0}^{1}e^{-(y+1)} dy=e^{-1}-e^{-2}=0.23[/latex] [latex]P_{eX_B}=\int_{0}^{1} f_{Y/X_B}(y)dy=\int_{0}^{1}e^{(y-1)} [1-u(y-1)]dy= \int_{0}^{1}e^{(y-1)} dy=e^{-1}-e^{-2}=0.23[/latex] [latex] P_e=P(X_A) \times 0.23+P(X_B) \times 0.23 =0.23[P(X_A)+P(X_B)]=0.23 [/latex]

Question 54 Consider a real valued source whose samples are independent and identically
distributed random variables with the probability density function, [latex]f(x)[/latex], as shown in
the figure. Consider a 1 bit quantizer that maps positive samples to value [latex] \alpha  [/latex] and others to value [latex] \beta  [/latex]. If [latex] \alpha ^* [/latex]and [latex] \beta ^* [/latex] are the respective choices for [latex] \alpha  [/latex] and [latex] \beta  [/latex] that minimize the mean square
quantization error, then [latex] (\alpha ^*- \beta ^*)= [/latex] _________ (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution:
[latex]\frac{1}{2} \times K \times 2+1 \times K=1\Rightarrow K=0.5[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned}
 f_X(x)&=mx+C \\ 
 &=0.25+C \;\;;\;(-2\leq x\leq 0) \\ 
when \; x &=-2 \Rightarrow f_X(x)=0\\ 
 0&=0.25x-2+C \\ 
 C&=0.5 \\ 
 f_X(x)&= \frac{1}{4}x+\frac{1}{2}=-2\leq x\leq 0\\ 
 f_X(x)&=0.5;\;\;0\leq x\leq 1 \\ 
 x_q&=\alpha ;\;\; for\; 0\leq x\leq 1 \\;
 x_q&= \beta  ;\;\; for\; -2\leq x\leq 0 \\;
\end{aligned}[/latex] Again, 
[latex]MSQ[Q_e]=E\left [ (X-X_q)^2 \right ][/latex] Quantization noise power 
[latex]=N_o[/latex] [latex]=MSQ[Q_e]=\int (X-X_a)^2 f_X(x)dx[/latex] for [latex]-2 \leq x\leq 0\Rightarrow N_Q=\int_{-2}^{0}(x-\beta )^2 \times \left ( \frac{1}{4}x+\frac{1}{2} \right )dx[/latex] [latex]=\int_{-2}^{0}[x^2+\beta ^2-2x\beta ] \left [ \frac{x}{4}+\frac{1}{2} \right ]dx[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow N_Q=\frac{\beta ^2}{2}+\frac{2}{3}\beta -\frac{1}{3}[/latex] [latex]N_Q[/latex]  to be minimum: [latex]\frac{dN_Q}{d\beta }=0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 2\beta +\frac{2}{3}=0[/latex] [latex]\beta =-\frac{2}{3}[/latex] for 
[latex]0\leq x\leq 1[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow N_Q=\int_{0}^{1}(x-\alpha )^2 \times \frac{1}{2}dx =\frac{1}{6} [(1-\alpha )^3+\alpha ^3][/latex] Similarly for 
[latex]'\alpha '[/latex] [latex]\frac{dN_Q}{d\alpha  }=0 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;\frac{1}{6} [3(1-\alpha )^2(-1)+3\alpha ^2]=0 [/latex] [latex]\alpha =1/2[/latex] For 
[latex]N_q[/latex] to be minimum [latex]\alpha -\beta =\frac{1}{2}-\left ( -\frac{2}{3} \right )=\frac{7}{6}=1.167[/latex]

question:
Question 55 In an electrostatic field, the electric displacement density vector, [latex] \vec{D}  [/latex], is given by [latex] \vec{D}(x,y,z)=(x^3\vec{i}+y^3\vec{j}+xy^2\vec{k})C/m^2  [/latex] ,
where [latex] \vec{i},\vec{j},\vec{k}  [/latex] are the unit vectors along x-axis, y-axis, and z-axis, respectively.
Consider a cubical region R centered at the origin with each side of length 1 m, and
vertices at ([latex]\pm 0.5 m, \pm 0.5 m, \pm 0.5 m  [/latex]). The electric charge enclosed within R is
_________ C (rounded off to two decimal places).
solution: [latex]\vec{D}(x,y,z)=(x^3\vec{i}+y^3\vec{j}+xy^2\vec{k})c/m^2[/latex] [latex]Q_{enc.}=\int _v \rho _v\cdot dV=\int (\triangledown \cdot \vec{D})dV[/latex] [latex]\triangledown \cdot \vec{D}=3x^2+3y^2[/latex] [latex]dV=dxdydz[/latex] [latex]\therefore \; Q_{enc.}=\int _v 3(x^2+y^2)dxdydz =3\left [ \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} x^2 dx  \int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dy \int_{-0.5}^{0.5} dz+\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dx\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}y^2dy\int_{-0.5}^{0.5}dz \right ][/latex] [latex] =3\left [ \frac{x^3}{3}|_{-0.5}^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1 + \frac{y^3}{3}|_{-0.5}^{0.5} \times 1 \times 1\right ] =0.25+0.25=0.5C[/latex]

Question 61 Mosquitoes pose a threat to human health. Controlling mosquitoes using
chemicals may have undesired consequences. In Florida, authorities have used
genetically modified mosquitoes to control the overall mosquito population. It
remains to be seen if this novel approach has unforeseen consequences. Which one of the following is the correct logical inference based on the
information in the above passage?
solution:
Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes may have
undesired consequence but it is not clear if using
genetically modified mosquitoes has any negative consequence.

options.A:
Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes is better than using genetically modified
mosquitoes because genetic engineering is dangerous
options.B:
Using genetically modified mosquitoes is better than using chemicals to kill
mosquitoes because they do not have any side effects
options.C:
Both using genetically modified mosquitoes and chemicals have undesired
consequences and can be dangerous
options.D:
Using chemicals to kill mosquitoes may have undesired consequences but it is
not clear if using genetically modified mosquitoes has any negative
consequence

inequalities?
solution: [latex] 2x-1 \gt 7 \Rightarrow 2x \gt 8\Rightarrow x \gt 4[/latex] [latex] 2x-9 \lt 1 \Rightarrow 2x \lt 10\Rightarrow x \lt 5[/latex] Combining both inequalities [latex] 4 \lt x \lt 5[/latex]

Question 63 Four points P(0, 1), Q(0,-3), R(-2,-1), and S(2, -1) represent the vertices
of a quadrilateral. What is the area enclosed by the quadrilateral?
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
PS&=\sqrt{(\sqrt{2})^2+(-2)^2}\\
&=\sqrt{8}\\
SQ&=\sqrt{4+4}=\sqrt{8}\\
QS&=\sqrt{4+4}=\sqrt{8}\\
PQ&=\sqrt{16}=4\\
RS&=\sqrt{16}=4\\
Arear&=\sqrt{8} \times \sqrt{8}=8 units
\end{aligned}[/latex]
